p: As in all the revised species, the most abundant compound in C. medica is limonene, but its percentage can decrease down to 51% ( Verzera et al., 2005), while other monoterpene compounds such as γ-terpinene, β-pinene or camphene are present at higher concentration, in comparison with species of C. reticulata cluster where these compounds are usually described in percentages below 1%. Thus, in C. medica oil, γ-terpinene, β-pinene or camphene can reach percentage of 31%, 9.7%, and 10%, respectively ( Lota et al., 1999; Aliberti et al., 2016; Petretto et al., 2016). Also C. medica presents higher concentrations of some sesquiterpenes, as is the case of ( E)-α-bergamotene ( Aliberti et al., 2016) or germacrene D ( Petretto et al., 2016), although their abundance is usually lower than 0.5%.
